UI_visible_response: The United States government's view on the "One China" policy is distinct from the People's Republic of China's (PRC) "One China Principle." The U.S. "One China Policy" does not recognize Taiwan as part of the PRC, and the U.S. has never recognized Taiwan as a part of the PRC2. Additionally, U.S. policy, though rarely stated publicly, treats Taiwan's political status as unresolved1. This nuanced position highlights the differences between how the U.S. and the PRC interpret the concept of "One China."
traffic_visible_response: The United States government's view on the "One China" policy is distinct from the People's Republic of China's (PRC) "One China Principle." The U.S. "One China Policy" does not recognize Taiwan as part of the PRC, and the U.S. has never recognized Taiwan as a part of the PRC [[2]]. Additionally, U.S. policy, though rarely stated publicly, treats Taiwan's political status as unresolved [[1]]. This nuanced position highlights the differences between how the U.S. and the PRC interpret the concept of "One China."
